awd_titl_txt: Simulation-Based Design of Polymer Nanocomposites for Structural Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
In conventional engineered materials, an engineering designer often selects a material from tabulated databases of products and completes an iterative process of checking the adequacy of the conceptual design for meeting performance requirements. The final engineering design is thus handicapped by the initial material selection. A material designer, on the other hand, works with a library of material compositions and processing methodologies with a goal to discover how new properties emerge from microstructure control, for example. The focus of material design is thus limited to achieving specific property enhancements without considering the end application of the material. There is a need to unify the material and engineering design processes so that new materials can be intentionally designed with the specific goal of incorporation into a useful product, and the engineering design can be freed from the upfront material-based constraints. This project will establish a concurrent design process combining top-down goal-oriented decision-making to optimize engineering system performance with bottom-up constraint-aware algorithms to efficiently search the domain of feasible material designs for polymer nanocomposites. This research project will provide innovation in design methodologies, enabling a competitive advantage to our nation's manufacturing industries as well as energy and defense technologies. 

This award supports fundamental research for the development of a new design paradigm termed Concurrent, Unified, State-aware Tailoring of Materials (CUSToM). The PIs will take a Bayesian approach to searching over the design domain, facilitating explicit consideration of the uncertainties in every aspect of the process. In the CUSToM framework, computer simulation (either empirical or first-principles based) is an integral part of the search process capturing the material scientist's domain knowledge. The hypothesis underlying this project is that the top-down search processes engrained in the CUSToM framework will yield products with superior performance compared to those obtained with conventional materials design. This hypothesis will be tested on the design of polymer nanocomposites with precisely determined material microstructure, composition, and processing methods for applications in wind energy; specifically high-strength, light-weight composites for next generation wind turbine blades. The broader impacts of this work will go beyond providing a new design paradigm for engineered materials to include the training of undergraduate and graduate researchers, exposure of undergraduate and graduate students to the world of entrepreneurship, and outreach to K-12 students in order to motivate them towards careers in STEM related fields.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project established a concurrent design process combining top-down, goal-oriented decision-making to optimize engineering system performance with bottom-up, constraint-aware algorithms that efficiently search the domain of feasible material designs for polymer nanocomposites. This research project provided innovation in design methodologies, enabling a competitive advantage to our nation’s manufacturing industries as well as energy and defense technologies. We developed a statistically robust framework for carrying out system design optimizations, all while working to improve and refine our ability to accurately model the material properties of a variety of polymer composites.

We completed a thorough literature review on Bayesian methods readily available for computer model calibration and developed a Bayesian framework that repurposes existing calibration frameworks for engineering design and implemented, tested, and refined this framework for design to better accommodate uncertainty with respect to model hyperparameters. We developed a method for using this framework to estimate Pareto fronts with quantified uncertainties. Subsequently, we developed a model for combining traditional model calibration with the repurposed “calibration-for-design” process, so that the relevant design procedure could be employed using a computer model that needs traditional model calibration (e.g. completing engineering design and model calibration in tandem). In parallel, we developed a state-aware model calibration framework using physics-guided generative adversarial network. We leveraged generative models in statistical machine learning guided by domain knowledge to enable the probabilistic inverse identification of state-dependent high-dimensional parameters.

We developed codes to enable the rapid development of high-fidelity finite-element models for composite materials considering microscale material properties. The codes we developed permit rapid sampling of microstructures and numerical homogenization of a periodic microstructure reinforced by randomly distributed spherical particles containing an interphase region. The model provided a high-fidelity representation of the material properties of a three-phase RVE consisting of matrix, filler, and an interphase layer. We studied the influence of the RVE size and mesh density on the predicted effective properties and developed a framework to numerically model and characterize a composite’s interphase as an alternative to traditional experimental methods, which are prone to biases and alterations of local properties at the matrix-filler interface. This framework was successfully applied to determine a composite’s interphase thickness and modulus, two parameters of high uncertainty, from conventional macroscopic property measurements.  The interphase parameters were uncovered by solving the inverse problem using a Bayesian inference approach, coupled with first-principles finite element analysis.  The approach was demonstrated for six composites, and the calibrated models agreed well with experimental measurements.

The research was widely disseminated through three publications in three disciplines that this work encompassed: chemical engineering and material science, statistics, and engineering design.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Sez Atamturktur Russcher
